Bug.Summery: Misleading removal of entries in (default classpath)
Bug.WithStack:
3.0M8 on Windows 2003
In the Run/Classpath tab, the DEL key can remove entries from the (default classpath) list, but they are actually not removed upon Run. The intention is that the "default" entry can be removed, but individual entries within the "default container" cannot be removed. Fixed in RuntimeClasspathViewer (org.eclipse.jdt.internal.debug.ui.classpath). The delete key was always enabled, but is now tied to the "REMOVE" action enablement. Please verify, Darin (S). Verified.

Bug.Summery: [CVS] rcinfo; CVS: lines; Commit dialog does not handle commit template well

Lines.Line: 2) The message starts with the template
3) The message ends with the template

Bug.WithStack:
Is rcinfo not supported?
@@
# rcsinfo ALL $CVSROOT/CVSROOT/rcstemplate
@@
The rcstemplate file:
@@
CVS: ---------------------------------------------------------------------- CVS: Please enter a commit message.
@@
I check out a module from CVS, add a file and commit it.
The template above will be shown in the text field; I now press Return (i.e. no message).
@@
cvs ci -m "/other/test.txt" RCS file: /opt/cvs/test/other/test.txt,v done Checking in test.txt; /opt/cvs/test/other/test.txt,v <-- test.txt initial revision: 1.1 done Mailing the commit message to 'test@test.com'. ok (took 0:00.430)
@@@@
Now I change the file and commit again; this time I enter "xx" and leave the template in place
cvs ci -m "xx CVS: ---------------------------------------------------------------------- CVS: Please enter a commit message. " "/other/test.txt" Checking in test.txt; /opt/cvs/test/other/test.txt,v <-- test.txt new revision: 1.2; previous revision: 1.1 done Mailing the commit message to 'test@test.com'. ok (took 0:00.390)
@@@@
Now if I look at the commit messages in the CVS Resource History the first entry will be "*** empty log message***" and the second will be: " xx CVS: ---------------------------------------------------------------------- CVS: Please enter a commit message. "
@@@@
If I do the same thing with vi on the commandline the template will be stripped and only "xx" will be the log message.
@@@@
So, shouldn't there be a second non-editable text field displaying the template?
Or the dialog should remember that it fetched a template and therefore strip it from the message it sends to the server?
@@@@
Forcing the user to always delete the template is not an option in my opinion. So what you are saying is that, after the user has hit OK on the Commit message dialog, the template should be be stripped from the message if:
1) The message equals the template 2) The message starts with the template 3) The message ends with the template
Currently, we only do 1) but need to do 2) and 3) as well. Is this what you mean? Created attachment 9152 fix
does a regex replace so the template can either be at the top, bottom or in between Forgot the response to comment 1.
Yes that's what I mean :D
I also implemented a more sophisticated approach which stripped any part of the template but it was overkill in my opinion. Fix released to HEAD verified in
Version: 3.1.0 Build id: 200409140800

Bug.Summery: problems with background jobs
Bug.WithStack:
Build N20040402
The nightly build is unusable due to problems with background jobs: they seem to get queued but not run, or only run spoadically. There is no progress indicator visible in the UI, either. I was having the same problem when testing runtime workbenches with UI projects loaded from HEAD. Reverting the UI projects to M8 fixed the problems. When I suspended the VM, I could see that the background jobs were running fine, but the progress view was still showing waiting and running jobs. I think this is a side effect Bug 56749 as no UI jobs were running as the isWorkbenchRunning returned false when it should have been true. As a result the progress view dropped all of its updates.
I cannot replicate this morning but I will leave this open for verfication when we get a nightly or integration build completing successfully. This was Bug 56749.

Bug.Summery: Cannot build a project in M8
Bug.WithStack:
I removed all traces of M7 and then installed M8, without any problems. I then created a new test java project and imported a couple of classes. I cannot get eclipse to manually build the project at all, the appropiate options are just grayed out, no matter what I do. Also the "select working set" action is disabled in the "build working set" meneu.
I also have my doubts whether the new "clean" action really works
Is it just me, my configuration. For the record I am running Fedora Core 1 (fully updated), with Sun J2SDK 1.4.2_04
For the time being I have gone back to M7, which seems stable and does everything I need for now. I've got exactly the same problem on windows XP with Sun J2SDK 1.4.2_03. If you install a fresh copy of Eclipse then autobuild is enabled by default. Since autobuild takes place in background without any dialog poping up you might not notice that building took place.
Moving to platform regarding the confusion of clean / build. Following up Dirk's comment, I reinstalled M8 and disabled the autobuild facility and yes I can now do a manual build. As Dirk said this is a bit confusing, we should always be able to do a manual build, regardless of whether eclipse does it behinds the scenes or not; this is not paranoria(?) but a developer just ensuring he knows the precise state the code is in. If there is nothing to build because the autobuild has done it job, then a buildall should do nothing, but it should not be disabled, perhaps changing an icon or the label colour is more appropiate. This is how I feel it should work.
For the time being I will be testing M8 with autobuild off. My use case: I use a couple of ant builders for creating a deployable project. These builders are not activated on an auto-build but in M8 I cannot use Build project to run them. Even after a 'Clean' I cannot use Build project (maybe because there are no original java resources in this project - it is just a copy of resources from another projects). I know that I can specify resources in the Ant build and when those changes the build occurs but I have to set up a method that works both Eclipse 2.1.x and Eclipse 3.0. It was a rather convenient way to use Builders. Now the only way I found to work is to 'Disable autobuild'->'Clean project'->'Build project'->'Enable autobuild'. It is far more complicated than the original 'Build project'.
I second the comment "we should always be able to do a manual build, regardless of whether eclipse does it behinds the scenes or not". That is the way it has always worked, there is no good reason to change it, and it can be *very* confusing when a project won't build, e.g., as I experienced, because of internal errors deleting resources - you can Clean the project but you can't seem to build it. I have no idea what combination of incantations finally got the project to build. *** Bug 58434 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** Some changes have been made to make this less confusing. Note that "Rebuild" has now been fully replaced by "Clean".

Bug.Summery: Make NaiveASTFlattener an API class

Lines.Line: - We use the formatter on the result. Of course the formatter doesn't run an
all kind of nodes, as by default only compilation units, body declarations,
statements and expressions can be formatted. There's some work to overcome
that limitation, done by the CodeFormatterUtil.fomat2(ASTNode..).
- Get a qualified names from Node or Type node instances , say a replacement
- Some code constructs an AST, flattens it, and then creates an AST on it,
again, to get bindings and compiler problems.
NaiveASTFlattener doesn't handle unicodes in keywords. Therefore it must not be
I don't see why we want this as an API if we have the AST rewriting.
I don't understand what you mean by "NaiveASTFlattener doesn't handle unicodes

expects an existing Compilation unit to apply changes to.

Bug.WithStack:
Make org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.NaiveASTFlattener an API class (it's currently internal).
There are several usages [from Martin]: - We use the formatter on the result. Of course the formatter doesn't run an all kind of nodes, as by default only compilation units, body declarations, statements and expressions can be formatted. There's some work to overcome that limitation, done by the CodeFormatterUtil.fomat2(ASTNode..). - Get a qualified names from Node or Type node instances , say a replacement for the methods Name.getQualifiedName(), - Some code constructs an AST, flattens it, and then creates an AST on it, again, to get bindings and compiler problems. NaiveASTFlattener doesn't handle unicodes in keywords. Therefore it must not be API until this is fixed. I don't see why we want this as an API if we have the AST rewriting. I don't understand what you mean by "NaiveASTFlattener doesn't handle unicodes in keywords". Note that the AST rewriter is more about 're'-writing. In its current state it expects an existing Compilation unit to apply changes to.
When you want to get the flattened version of a Do statement, you go into this method: public boolean visit(DoStatement node) { this.buffer.append("do ");//$NON-NLS-1$ node.getBody().accept(this); this.buffer.append(" while (");//$NON-NLS-1$ node.getExpression().accept(this); this.buffer.append(");");//$NON-NLS-1$ return false; }
This means that the 'do' keyword or the 'while' keyword will be replaced with "do" and "while" even if in the source code they were written as: \u0064\u006f for 'do' and the same thing for 'while'. An operation on source code should never change the code. If unicode were used, they have to be used after the operation through the naive flattener. So exposing the naive flattener as is is not an option. It needs work to be used as an API. The NaiveASTFlattener does not take into account the source code from which the AST was created (that's why is called "naive"). Obviously the spec would make this fact clear. This is why I really don't see why it is useful. Using it can lead to bugs with the usage of unicodes. An API class has to support unicodes by default. Will reconsider post 3.0 Can we reconsider this for 3.1? We currently have an exact copy of the flattener in jdt.ui and I just got a bug of an issue (bug 78496) where we forgot to keep the two in-sync.
We could think about a better name to avoid any confusions with the AST rewriter, e.g. ASTNodesToString visitor, however I think NaiveASTFlattener is not confusing.
We could also think to merge the NaiveASTFlattener with the ASTRewriteFlattener which does exactly the same as the NaiveASTFlattener except that it does not access the node properties directly but through a bottle neck method Object getAttribute(ASTNode parent, StructuralPropertyDescriptor childProperty) that so the rewriter can take the described AST rewrite changes into account.
That indirection is of course less performant, but adds more possibilities.
I don't believe this should be exposed as an API. Why not? I think comment 5 and comment 6 contain good point against this class as API. I don't see what the need can be to have this as an API. This flattener doesn't handle unicodes and doesn't reflect the source code entered by the user. You mix different things. There is AST rewriting: Get an AST created from existing source, make changes to it and have your code changed according to these changes. That's the AST rewrite infrastructure.
The NaiveASTFlattener simply helps you to flatten any kind of AST tree or tree segment, regardless if it was created from source or by hand (ast.new..) and just generates a source represetation from it. As I suggested, rename it to 'ASTNodesToString' or something if you really think the name is misleading.
If you're intersted why this is useful, look at the users of ASTNodes.asString, or how our class 'ASTFlattener' is used. Note that we copied this class as it obviously was useful. My concern is that I think people won't use it for the right purpose. The javadoc comment clearly says that it should be use only for debugging purpose.
* Internal AST visitor for serializing an AST in a quick and dirty fashion. * For various reasons the resulting string is not necessarily legal * Java code; and even if it is legal Java code, it is not necessarily the string * that corresponds to the given AST. Although useless for most purposes, it's * fine for generating debug print strings.
So it would be a mistake to use it for a different purpose. Even worse it the fact that the code might not be legal java code. An API needs to be well specified and returns something predictable.
Jim, any comment? Obviously would the comment have to be changed. I'm not aware that the generated code would be non-legal Jim, can we reconsider this. We are currently maintaining a copy of this which feels the wrong thing to do. Dirk, I'm concerned about exposing it as a class. I would prefer to have it surfaces as a single method that returned a string for the given node. We would need to spec where this method deals adds whitespace. Q: do you care at all about whitespace at all (so long as it adds enough)? In particular, would it be any more or less useful if it never contained line breaks? - we don't care about line breaks. However the white space should be added in a way that the resulting string is somehow human readable.
- a method that converts a node into a string would be sufficient.
However I don't see the difference of such a mehtod compared to makeing the visitor API. The second would provide more flexibility. *** Bug 113636 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** As of now 'LATER' and 'REMIND' resolutions are no longer supported. Please reopen this bug if it is still valid for you. Still a valid request.

Bug.Summery: [Problems] Problems view should pop up without stealing the focus
Bug.WithStack:
When the problems view is set to be a fast view and to open automatically upon new errors or warnings, it pops up stealing the focus from the current editor. This prevents from continuing typing after saving a line, for example.
The view should not steal the focus when it opens up automatically. The problems view no longer opens automatically

Bug.Summery: [browser] SWT Browser Widget Crashes Workbench on XP when loading the Shockwave Plug-in
Bug.WithStack:

Bug.Summery: TrayItem buttons 'feels' inversed on windows

Lines.Line: - double left-click fires default selection, as does double right-click
- single right-click fires MenuDetect, for showing a menu

Bug.WithStack:
This may not be a bug (according to you), but according to standard use of windows's system tray icons, events are inverted.
That is : I get a defaultSelection event when double clicking with the right mouse button I get a Selection event when left clicking it.
It sounds that right click should trigger the Selection Event (in order to show up a menu), and double-left click should trigger the default selection.
I've looked at TrayItem.java , and by changing the "int messageProc (int hwnd, int msg, int wParam, int lParam)" method, I can get the correct result (at least on windows) here the new code for this mehtod :
int messageProc (int hwnd, int msg, int wParam, int lParam) { switch (lParam) { case OS.WM_RBUTTONUP: postEvent (SWT.Selection); break; case OS.WM_LBUTTONDBLCLK: case OS.WM_RBUTTONDBLCLK: postEvent (SWT.DefaultSelection); break; case OS.WM_RBUTTONDOWN: { /* * Feature in Windows. When the user clicks outside of the * menu to cancel it, the menu is not hidden until an event * is processed. If another application is the foreground * window, then the menu is not hidden. The fix is to force * the tray icon message window to the foreground. */ OS.SetForegroundWindow (hwnd); sendEvent (SWT.MenuDetect); // widget could be disposed at this point if (isDisposed()) return 0; break; } } display.wakeThread (); return 0; }
some comments :
I've also changed the up / down order (it sounds more logical to trigger selection on the 'up' event, and so, the hack for the menu works with the 'down' event).
Feel free to test it. Maybe a work-arround will be needed if it doesn't work correctly on other platforms. example Tray snippet: http://dev.eclipse.org/viewcvs/index.cgi/%7Echeckout% 7E/platform-swt-home/snippits/snippet143.html
- double left-click fires default selection, as does double right-click - single right-click fires MenuDetect, for showing a menu
These behaviours match the tray icons created by other applications on my machine. Marking report as WORKSFORME. If I've missed something here then please follow up.
Ok, thanks for the snippet, I build the javadoc of SWT this morning (as the ones on eclipse website doesn't look like being updated), or maybe I'm using a wrong bookmark : http://dev.eclipse.org/viewcvs/index.cgi/~checkout~/platform-swt-home/dev.html#snippets
Anyway, my javadocs weren't refering any MenuDetect event (I looked in TrayItem , Item and Widget).
Maybe it would be good to document it in the javadocs.
I've also seen in your widget that Show and Hide events may be triggered, (I haven't succeeded to trigger them with your snippet), those events don't seem to be documented either.
Thanks a lot for your quick reply, everything works for me now :) This was a definite oversight in the documentation, which I've now fixed. Thanks for pointing this out.
fyi: Hide and Show is fired when TrayIcon.setVisible(boolean) is invoked.

Bug.Summery: Error Log View does not scale
Bug.WithStack:
I had an *old* workspace, with many log entries. At some point, I decided to open "Show View > PDE Runtime > Error Log". It never returned. I had to kill my eclipse. Then, I checked the workspace/.metadata/.log file. Sure. The file measures 250MB. That said, The Error Log View should just do the first X entries and then bail out with a message. In a more modest scenario, with a log file of 'only' 25MB, Error Log View performance is not acceptable. We could do that, but the problem is that the first x entries are the oldest x entries, not the latest x entries, and hence this problem. You mean, you cannot go to the end of the file, go back 1MB, then find the start of the first Log entry you find from there, and continue to the end? But that would be work :-). The format of the log file makes this very difficult. As far as I know, the Log file consists of entries starting with:
!ENTRY org.eclipse.ui.cheatsheets 4 0 Apr 02, 2004 10:02:56.594
How hard is to use a random access file, go to a location an scan ahead to the first occurrence of "\n!ENTRY" ?
BTW. Why is the Error Log in PDE? It should be in Basic/UI. Any Eclipse User could benefit from it, not just plugin developers.
>How hard is to use a random access file, go to a location an scan >ahead to the first occurrence of "\n!ENTRY" ? This part is not difficult. But there is more to it. For instance we have to associate every entry with a particular session. The session data is printed only once to the file. If the session data is outside this 1MB range (e.g. in the beginning of the 25MB file at worst), then we're back to the same problem of reading too much, or we would be losing functionality.
In any event, choking on a 250MB file is not acceptable, and we have to do something, but the solution is not going to be simple.
>BTW. Why is the Error Log in PDE? It should be in Basic/UI. Any Eclipse >User could benefit from it, not just plugin developers.
See bug 50517

The format of the log file makes this very difficult. As far as I know, the Log file consists of entries starting with:
!ENTRY org.eclipse.ui.cheatsheets 4 0 Apr 02, 2004 10:02:56.594
How hard is to use a random access file, go to a location an scan ahead to the first occurrence of "\n!ENTRY" ?
BTW. Why is the Error Log in PDE? It should be in Basic/UI. Any Eclipse User could benefit from it, not just plugin developers.
>How hard is to use a random access file, go to a location an scan >ahead to the first occurrence of "\n!ENTRY" ? This part is not difficult. But there is more to it. >BTW. Why is the Error Log in PDE? It should be in Basic/UI. Any Eclipse >User could benefit from it, not just plugin developers.

When a cheat sheet is shown, resizing the workbench is very sluggish. The workbench redrawing is not smooth. Close the cheat sheet and resizing the workbench becomes smooth again. Do we understand what is going on here? Is this a problem with the cheat sheet, SWT, or it just an example of a case where we should do less, even at the cost of it not looking as good? I have seen a similar problem in a simple SWT Text widget that contains a lot of code. When resizing the parent shell, the widget is calculating so much that the contents of the shell gets redrawn maybe once per 3/4 seconds. Cheat sheets redraws faster than that, but is still not acceptable. Weird guess: Is GEF being used? I don't think we can do something radical here. The content of the cheat sheet is a number of composites and layouts and as you resize the workbench, they are constantly resized and layouts recomputed. A dedicated control (browser) would be better in the same sense as StyledText had to be written anew to only redraw areas that are absolutely necessary when dirty. We can analyze if we can elliminate unneeded 'layout' calls but it is fairly hard. Resizing changes the width of the view. This changes the wrapping of the individual text widgets, which in turn changes the height. Changes in the height affect the ScrolledComposite widget that need to constantly recompute scroll bar visibility. If we find a way to achive the same effect with less repaints and layouts, the performance will be better. No, GEF has not been used. The cheat sheet uses ScrolledComposite that hosts an Eclipse Form. A combination of TableWrapLayout and GridLayout is used to control placement of the cheat sheet parts. These layouts are costly to compute when called in a rapid succession. Some UIs circumvent the problem of the need of showing/hiding scrollbars by always showing them. When they are not needed, use disabled scrollbar, but do not hide it. This makes the UI more stable, and I bet, double-bet, relayout and redraw will be much faster. I think the disabled scrollbars would not have as nice an appearance. Q: If most of the content repositions/resizes is it better to turn off redraw first? We can experiment and fine-tune the performance. However, just for the record, cheat sheet is actually snappier now since we ported it to Eclipse Forms than it was before. In other words, we are not talking about a regression here, rather a long-standing problem that actually got better but apparently not good enough yet. Laffra's Law 1: Performance of any software program inevitable becomes a space-time tradeoff. -- Chris Laffra Laffra's Law 2: Performance of any software program is inevitable related to strings. -- Chris Laffra In this case, Law 2 applies. Being the author of TableWrapLayout, I know there is a lot of room for improvement - it is definitely not the best and fastest as it is now (the focus was on getting it to work first). When you switch from SWT.WRAP to SWT.NULL, the label is always computed on one long line. That in turn makes the entire layout less 'jumpy' becuase the height does not change with the width. It does not help much - we need it to wrap, so this is just an academic exercise. I welcome all suggestions from SWT developers that know the real price of certain method calls. And by 'seasoned SWT developer that knows how to write good custom widgets', I usually mean 'Veronika', hence I am adding her to the CC list :-). After a few code fixes here are the numbers I'm getting to compare FormText to Label with SWT.WRAP: FormText | Label with SWT.WRAP ---------------------------------- 821 | 581 611 | 390 601 | 390 531 | 321 511 | 281 491 | 280 481 | 280 481 | 300 The times listed above are in milliseconds. The scenario is to start Eclipse self-hosted in debug-mode with a fresh workspace. Close the Welcome and launch the "Hello, World Application" cheat sheet from the Help menu. Close the Cheat Sheet view and repeat previous step. From what I can tell, over half the time is spent in the control.layout(); call of CheatSheetViewer.initCheatSheetView(). From what I can tell, FormText is about 50% slower than the native Label. This is not bad at all, considering that it does more and is also Java code i.e. not native. It is quite possible than TableWrapLayout (also from Eclipse Forms) that is far from optimal could benefit from some performance tune up. It is quite complex and is also written with focus on function, less on performance. Found this bug while scanning through the performance bugs... interesting discussion with good findings. However, the current priority (P3) is a fair assignment for this bug and I suggest that it is treated as such. OK. I give up :-) I was just rattling the cage a bit when I changed the priority number. Sorry. Chris, I have released some changes to HEAD. Could you check if there is any improvements on your end. I came across major performance problem using Forms API while creating relatively complex forms. The problem is not only with the cheat sheet but with any Form containing certain number of complex controls like ExpandableComposite, Section or FormText. I partially fixed problem with ExpandableComposite. The fix is rough but it can help you to understand the reason of the problem. I tried to find appropriate open bug in eclipse’s bugzilla and found the cheat sheet redraw issue. Attached are two sample plug-in projects with the same view before and after the fix. The view contains ScrolledForm with one Section and 20 ExpandableComposite controls. It redraws very slow, 5 - 7 seconds to expand/collapse expandable composite and causes even worse problem than the cheat sheet when resizing the workbench. If you run the sample in profiler, it will show about 800 calls of ExpandableComposite$ExpandableLayout.computeSize() for each redraw or mouse click to expand/collapse a composite. But the number of ExpandableComposites in the view is only 20. Since the ExpandableLayout.computeSize() is expensive these calls take about 90% of the redraw time. This enormous number of computeSize() calls starts from ScrolledForm.reflow() that does the following: 1. calls content.getBody().layout() method that computes the body size by calling computeSize() of its children 2. content.layout() - guess does the same 3. then calls super.reflow() -> SharedScrolledComponent.reflow(): a. and again getContent().layout() method that calls computeSize() of its children b. after this it calls computeSize() directly c. then getContent().setSize() that does content re-layout again with computeSize() for all the children. d. then setMinSize() which causes widget event SWT.Resize (listener is in the SharedScrolledComposite constructor). The listener calls reflow() second time that repeats steps from 1 to 3.c … I guess there are other places where computeSize() is also called. For example, layout() method of Composite computes sizes of children by calling their computeSize(). Then resizes child controls by Control.setBounds() method and if a child is Composite then setBounds() causes its layout() call which consequently, again calls computeSize() of its children as well as computeMinimumSize() and computeMaximumSize(). I might be mistaken in some details listed above but not in general and the number of computeSize() calls is a fact. What I tried is to cache computed sizes in ExpandableLayout class. You can import both sample projects in eclipse, launch runtime workspace and compare two versions of the view - “Sample Form (Original)” and “Sample Form (Fixed)”. The same happens in the cheat sheet - computeSize() of FormText is expensive and in addition is called multiple, unnecessary times each time the form resizes or expandable composites expand/collapse. My sample fix affected only one class – org.eclipse.ui.forms.widgets.ExpandableComposite. I did not update the original class but created its copy in my sample plug-in and modified it (ModifiedExpandableComposite). I also created copy of FormToolkit class, which actually does not have any relation with the problem fix, and just added a method for ModifiedExpandableComposite creation. You can do diff between the original ExpandableComposite and the modified one to see the changes. Created attachment 14408 sample project demonstrating forms api performance problem Created attachment 14409 modified project demonstrating possible resolution of the performance problem The patch I've attached to bug 73716 will fix this. Note: that part of the problem is due to SWT's ScrolledComposite: 1. Each time ScrolledComposite calls setVisible on its scroll bars, it fires a resize event (which can happen 2x per layout). 2. ScrolledComposite attaches a resize listener to itself and its content area... each listener will call resize(), which triggers an additional layout(true). Using layout(true) flushes all the layout caches, ensuring the worst possible cache reuse. This means that each layout can trigger up to 4 additional layouts. This would cause infinite recursion if it wasn't for the flags inside ScrolledComposite.resize(). The performance improvement is such that we can consider this defect fixed. Verified in I20050214-0927. Redraw is very fast now. Nice work.

I came across major performance problem using Forms API while creating relatively complex forms. The problem is not only with the cheat sheet but with any Form containing certain number of complex controls like ExpandableComposite, Section or FormText. I partially fixed problem with ExpandableComposite. The fix is rough but it can help you to understand the reason of the problem. I tried to find appropriate open bug in eclipse’s bugzilla and found the cheat sheet redraw issue. Attached are two sample plug-in projects with the same view before and after the fix. The view contains ScrolledForm with one Section and 20 ExpandableComposite controls. It redraws very slow, 5 - 7 seconds to expand/collapse expandable composite and causes even worse problem than the cheat sheet when resizing the workbench. If you run the sample in profiler, it will show about 800 calls of ExpandableComposite$ExpandableLayout.computeSize() for each redraw or mouse click to expand/collapse a composite. But the number of ExpandableComposites in the view is only 20. Since the ExpandableLayout.computeSize() is expensive these calls take about 90% of the redraw time. This enormous number of computeSize() calls starts from ScrolledForm.reflow() that does the following: 1. calls content.getBody().layout() method that computes the body size by calling computeSize() of its children 2. content.layout() - guess does the same 3. then calls super.reflow() -> SharedScrolledComponent.reflow(): a. and again getContent().layout() method that calls computeSize() of its children b. after this it calls computeSize() directly c. then getContent().setSize() that does content re-layout again with computeSize() for all the children. d. then setMinSize() which causes widget event SWT.Resize (listener is in the SharedScrolledComposite constructor). The listener calls reflow() second time that repeats steps from 1 to 3.c … I guess there are other places where computeSize() is also called. For example, layout() method of Composite computes sizes of children by calling their computeSize(). Then resizes child controls by Control.setBounds() method and if a child is Composite then setBounds() causes its layout() call which consequently, again calls computeSize() of its children as well as computeMinimumSize() and computeMaximumSize(). I might be mistaken in some details listed above but not in general and the number of computeSize() calls is a fact. What I tried is to cache computed sizes in ExpandableLayout class. You can import both sample projects in eclipse, launch runtime workspace and compare two versions of the view - “Sample Form (Original)” and “Sample Form (Fixed)”. The same happens in the cheat sheet - computeSize() of FormText is expensive and in addition is called multiple, unnecessary times each time the form resizes or expandable composites expand/collapse. My sample fix affected only one class – org.eclipse.ui.forms.widgets.ExpandableComposite. I did not update the original class but created its copy in my sample plug-in and modified it (ModifiedExpandableComposite). I also created copy of FormToolkit class, which actually does not have any relation with the problem fix, and just added a method for ModifiedExpandableComposite creation. You can do diff between the original ExpandableComposite and the modified one to see the changes. Created attachment 14408 sample project demonstrating forms api performance problem Created attachment 14409 modified project demonstrating possible resolution of the performance problem The patch I've attached to bug 73716 will fix this. Note: that part of the problem is due to SWT's ScrolledComposite: 1. Each time ScrolledComposite calls setVisible on its scroll bars, it fires a resize event (which can happen 2x per layout). 2. ScrolledComposite attaches a resize listener to itself and its content area... each listener will call resize(), which triggers an additional layout(true). Using layout(true) flushes all the layout caches, ensuring the worst possible cache reuse. This means that each layout can trigger up to 4 additional layouts. This would cause infinite recursion if it wasn't for the flags inside ScrolledComposite.resize(). The performance improvement is such that we can consider this defect fixed. Verified in I20050214-0927. Redraw is very fast now. Nice work.

Bug.Summery: Console cannot parse stacktraces from JRockit
Bug.WithStack:
Clicking on a stacktrace (generated by JRockit) in the console gives you a dialog saying the source could not be found. The reason is that JRockit's stacktraces are formated a little bit differently. They include the method signature:
java.lang.Exception: sdsd at MyClass.main([Ljava.lang.String;)V(R.java:16)
Thus the parsing code in JavaStackTraceHyperlink needs to be updated. I will attach a patch for M8 which fixes this. Bug.Summery: Local update site doesn't refresh until site.xml is explicitly touched
Bug.WithStack:
Build 3.0 M8
When building a local update site, and testing it (using the update manager), I initially got my feature wrong (had forgotten to include the feature.properties). So I fixed that, and regenerated the update site.
When testing it, it was still wrong. I had to manually touch the site.xml file so as to cause the update manager to refresh.
This is counter-intuitive, a refresh should occur as soon as any of the files on the update site is modified. OK, this is Update. Reassigning back to PDE. Alhough this is not a PDE issue, the Update team made a decision to not drop the internal site cashe when each feature JAr is new, only when site.xml is newer for performance reasons. This is a valid compromise that only hurts site development in PDE.
A proposed solution is for PDE UI site builder to 'touch' site.xml each time build or build all is issued. This will cause Update to drop the cache for the site. This is an easy change. Unsure if it is the same bug or not, but when changing the category label in site.xml (resulting in the file being touched), then rebuilding the site; a local update site doesn't get refreshed in the end.
In order to see the latest state, I had to copy the local site elsewhere and add this new site to the update manager. PDE certainly touches the site.xml after building. It turns out that calling IResource.touch() on an IResource does not change the timestamp on the resource, which is probably what Update wants. Calling touch() only marks it as modified for resource building purposes.
Fixed now by explicitly calling java.io.File.setLastModified (System.currentTimeMillis) whenever the site is built. Marking as fixed. Before we forget about this defect: if you reach down to change the underlying file in the file system, wouldn't that make the related resource 'out of sync', requiring a refresh? I may be wrong, but it may cause problems with all the operations that require files to be in sync (for example, CVS). Perhaps a dual operation where you both 'touch' the file in the file system and mark it as up to date in th workspace is in order. Refresh always gets called at the end of the build site operation so that the user would see the new JARs, folders and zip logs generated, if any. That makes me happy again :-).

Bug.Summery: Infinite recursion in CodeGenUtil.snoozeAlarm with circular references
Bug.WithStack:
Infinite recursion in CodeGenUtil.snoozeAlarm with circular references
Open up an Empty. Drop two buttons on the free form. Select the first button. Change the property sheet to Show Advanced Properties. Change the nextFocusableComponent to jButton1. Select the second button. Change the nextFocusableComponent to jButton. Add a actionPerformed event to one of the buttons. Change the text of the println message in the event and wait for codegen to sync.
It will go into an infinite recursion... you'll eventually get a stack overflow. This will occur if two beans each refer the other as a property, in some cases CodeGen will force a refresh so that containers can react and reLayout components.
This code had a bug in it. Fixed M1 released, move all resolved to Verified, as prelude to closing. M1 released, move all resolved/verified to Closed.

Bug.WithStack:
M8 (Build id: 200403261517)
I needed to define a product with my own id to test Intro contributions. I wanted to just create a product that is the platform, but with a different ID.
The only way I could get it to work if to use the following:
<extension id="coolProduct" point="org.eclipse.core.runtime.products"> <product name="MyCoolProduct" id="org.eclipse.ui.intro.examples.coolProduct" application="org.eclipse.ui.ide.workbench" description="MyCoolProduct">

simple id at the extension level had to be the "short" version of the id, and I *had* to define an explicit id at product element level. Bug.Summery: Update site builder should create output folders on demand
Bug.WithStack:
Build 3.0M8
When configuring my update site, I used the defaults 'features' & 'plugins' folder which got created. I then shared this project to CVS, before having generated the site (features&plugins were empty).
Sometimes later, I got it back from CVS, and the folders were missing, since empty folders aren't shared by CVS.
Next build of site did fail, with empty logs !?! and I figured by myself that the missing output folders were the cause of this issue. Adding them back manually made it work again.

Bug.Summery: [Contexts] Action visible even though command context disabled
Bug.WithStack:
Using M8.
The "Step Into Selection" command is contributed by the Java debugger. It is scoped to the debug context, which is enabled when a debug session is active. However, the command is always visible in the "Run" menu, even when the debug context is disabled. For example, launch a new empty workspace, open the Java perspective, and open the "Run" menu - the action "Step Into Selection" appears.
Currently, the action has an "enablement" attribute on it to enable the action only when the java debugger is active. We should migrate this to use a "Java Debugging" context instead (but we don't have that support yet). Could this be causing the action to appear? The relevant action contribution and command definition follow:
<action

Using M8.
The "Step Into Selection" command is contributed by the Java debugger. It is scoped to the debug context, which is enabled when a debug session is active. However, the command is always visible in the "Run" menu, even when the debug context is disabled. For example, launch a new empty workspace, open the Java perspective, and open the "Run" menu - the action "Step Into Selection" appears.
Currently, the action has an "enablement" attribute on it to enable the action only when the java debugger is active. We should migrate this to use a "Java Debugging" context instead (but we don't have that support yet). Could this be causing the action to appear? Bug.Summery: add "label"element to probekit mode/editor
Bug.WithStack:
The label element is a replacement for name/description attributes. The name and description elements will become deprecated and the editor will not show or modify them, the editor will work only with the label element.
Allan please add a comment about how you want to handle the old values, otherwise there will be no label when opening old probe files.
Here is a sample XML: <probekit> <label xml:lang="en" name="sample" description="This is an example." /> <label xml:lang="fr" name="échantillon" description="C'est un exemple." /> <probe> ... contents of a probe here ... </probe> </probekit>
The element ref: <xsd:element maxOccurs="unbounded" minOccurs="0" ref="label"/>
The element declaration: <xsd:element name="label"> <xsd:complexType ecore:name="Label"> <xsd:attribute ref="xml:lang"/> <xsd:attribute name="name" type="xsd:string" use="required"/> <xsd:attribute name="description" type="xsd:string" use="optional"/> </xsd:complexType> </xsd:element> There is no problem with "old values" ... no probes exist today which use <name> or <description> as elements directly below <probekit>. Yes, I understand there will be no label in an old (Hyades 1.2 or 1.3) probe file. That's why <label> is optional: so the new model is backward-compatible. We'll deal with old probes in software either generating a default label or reporting an error when you try to do something that requires a label. Bug.Summery: [Content Assist] Weird behavior for Content Assist in AIX

Lines.Line: 3) type 'm'<^SPC> to create the main function
4) Inside the main function, type 'm' <^SPC> again.

Bug.WithStack:
Eclipse M8 (200403261517) CDT (200403291152) AIX OS
I am noticing weird behavior in AIX (or it may be common to motif). It is reproducible most of the time.
Steps: 1) Create standard project 2) Create a cpp file 3) type 'm'<^SPC> to create the main function 4) Inside the main function, type 'm' <^SPC> again.
After doing this action, the drop down of the content assist shows up for a fraction of second and disappears. The cursor is lost and I can't type anymore. I have take the mouse and insert the cursor again. However, if I try again, it will do the same.
It is worth demoing. Assigning to Hoda ... next time you are in the office w/an AIX box, give it a whirl ... From Hoda, this is a platform issue that happens on AIX (and maybe common for a motif OS). This is not a Linux nor a Windows issue.
Motif behaves differently compared to Linux or Windows when, for example, you right click (for a context menu) and release. In Linux/windows, the context menu stays up. In motif, it disappears. I have a suspicion that the problem I am seeing in Motif/AIX is related to this Motif behavior. Same problem as reported in bug 33165

Bug.Summery: JavaDocExport: if destination path has spaces, the JavaDoc is generated into the incorrect (truncated) path or fails [javadoc]
Bug.WithStack:
Steps to reproduce (Eclipse3.0M8): Create a project with any name; Create some classes there; Execute Export->Javadoc. In the wizard, in the destination editbox, type any name that contains spaces. If the spaces are only in the last segment of the path (say, c:\tmp\my project), the javadoc is just generated in the incorrect (truncated) location (in this example, c:\tmp\my).
If there are spaces before the last segment (e.g., c:\Documents and Settings\user\My Documents\my project), generation only produces 2 empty folders (in this example, C:\Documents and the destination that was typed) and fails to do anything else. Also, spaces in the path of libraries referenced by the project are treated as command line separators.
E.g. if the project references the two Jar-Archives C:\Java XML\dom.jar and C:\Java XML\sax.jar, executing the Javadoc wizard produces the following error output:
javadoc: Illegal package name: "XML\dom.jar;C:\Java" javadoc: Illegal package name: "XML\sax.jar"

Bug.Summery: Ignore serialVersionUID hiding another field
Bug.WithStack:
When I enabled the compiler warning Advanced -> Field declaration hides another field or variable, I get the warning:
The field Two.serialVersionUID is hiding a field from type One.
This is pretty simple to reproduce: public class One implements Serializable{ static final long serialVersionUID = 1234567890L; }
public class Two extends One{ static final long serialVersionUID = 987654321L; }
I'd suggest that serialVersionUID should be ignored for this set of warnings. I agree. We already treat it special when flagging unused private members.
Created attachment 9237 ignore serialization fields during fieldHiding
This checks for the serialVersionUID and serialPersistentFields. Does it matter that there is no check to see if the class implements java.io.Serializable? It doesn't particularly matter to me if it checks that the class implements java.io.Serializable. As far as I know it's legal (though silly/useless) to define serialVersionUID whether it does or not.
This is offtopic, I know, but I think it'd be great to have a separate rule which checks that a Serializable class: -defines a serialVersionUID -contains only members that are Serializable, transient or static -has a unique serialVersionUID (check and compare) -does not extend a class that *can't* be serialized, such as a socket or stream or database connection etc
I've already implemented the above checks in my code by abusing Javadoc doclets, so I don't really need it. But perhaps someone else could benefit from such a thing. Patch looks good. This is the check we had in #unusedPrivateField. Fixed. Added regression test: NegativeTest#test416. Verified in 200405180816 I think this bug is back in the Kepler release

Bug.Summery: Calculation of off screen location for remote VM being done via syncExec()
Bug.WithStack: The calculation of the location for the remote VM UI's is being done synchronously in the display thread - which causes the background snippet update process to wait indefinitely. The calculation of the location should be farmed off to the remote vm. This is being done in the BeanAwtUtilies.getOffScreenLocation() method. This is an easy fix to do. We need to farm it off because as screens get bigger we may eventually wind up with one that is 10000x10000 and so we can't use our hard-coded size anymore. The fix has been released to HEAD. Snippet update works fine in M20050824.

Bug.Summery: [KeyBindings] Losing key bindings in debug mode
Bug.WithStack:
In 3.0M8 I set my key bindings to F10 for Step Over, F11 for Step Into F5 for resume and F6 for debug last launched. These key bindings either don't stick after the OK button is pressed or revert their behavior at some future point. F10 becomes "show accelerators" and F5 reverts to Step Into. I set these keys for the Debugging, Debugging in Java, and In Windows contexts with equal failure. One thing we noticed was that the context designation of the keys was often blank in the preferences dialog. It seemed that this was the case if the key had another binding in the default set. This seems wrong. There is also no way to remove a default binding. You will not be able to bind "F10" on Windows XP. "F10" means "Show Menu" on Windows XP (and Linux-GTK as well). Then the set key bindings page needs to say that when you try it. In any case, this is not something "set in stone" just something for usability. There are Windows apps out there (from microsfot) which use the F10 key for other things. I think it perfectly acceptable that the F10 capability could be overridable if the person doing it was made suitable aware that they were disabling this capability. Also, this would only pertain to the F10 key. I was seeing the problem with F5 and F11 as well. There are technical limitations from Platform UI's perspective that prevent us from allowing F10 easily. It is possible to do it with a hack, but that hack wouldn't allow the key binding to work in dialogs or non-workbench windows.
It's a good point that we should warn the user, but somewhat challenging. These keys change from platform to platform, and from version to version (of the window manager). It makes it hard to provide useful information to the user.
Can we leave that issue?
I'm interested in fixing the fact that your key bindings seem to be disappearing on you. Can you provide a clear reproducible case for that? My test case was just setting the 3 keys I was interested in and having them disappear. They haven't disappeared since I set them to be In Windows as well as Debugging and Debugging Java, although the F10 issue will habe to be addressed. The problem there is that I am coming from a corporate standard with MSDEV of using F10 for step into.
I think the F10 issue may be separate but I feel that if you don't tell people when they set the key that you will get more bug reports. Maybe don't even allow it as a possibly key for that field? Isn't there some kiond of flag you could add in the host specifc key support that you could check during key binding so that people not on XP could bind the key? Honestly, you're the first person to report that F10 can't be bound, and it's been like that for a while. If I get more bug reports about it, then I might try to do something about it. But right now, I feel there are more important things to work on.
Now, can you please provide exact reproducible steps for the key bindings going away? F10 bound perfectly fine in M5, M6, and M7. M8 was the first time I saw bindings go away and the first time F10 didn't bind. I'll try to work on reproducable steps later today. I have also had this problem. I am also unable to remove the default bindings in the "Debugging" context. I'm using M8.
I have had a similar problem trying to map F6 to "Debug Last Launched". I have had F6 mapped this way in the "Windows" context and the "Editing Java Source" context for most of M8. The mapping works most of the time. However, sometimes the mapping is temporarily lost. The symptoms are that the key doesn't work and the key printstring no longer shows up on the Run menu. Occasionally, the key printstring doesn't show up on the menu, but the key works anyway. After starting a new debug session using the menu item, the key usually comes back when I get ready to debug the next time.
The mapping is still in the Workbench->Keys list and I do not have to reestablish it. I can restart eclipse and the key will show up again.
I have noticed that the key seems to be missing sometimes when a debug session ends in an unusual manner. For me, debug sessions are often terminated because of code changes that cannot be resolved. Occasionally, the debug session won't come up (for unknown reasons) and I have to do some combination of killing the process from Eclipse or the task manager. The key mapping isn't always lost, but it seems to increase the chances.
I'm sorry that I don't have reproducible steps.
I don't recall having this problem in M7. Maybe there's a timing issue?
I can reproduce the problem when trying to bind F7 to 'step into'. Binding Ctrl-S or Ctrl-F7 to 'step into' works fine. Binding F7 to 'step into' does not work. Using I200405060200 is this still a problem? No problen anymore. No it works! Thanks. I never really figured out what was going wrong in this particular case (though I have my suspicions), so I'm closing this as WORKSFORME. Moving to verified to get them out of my list of bugs to verify for M9.
